properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wind chill values between minus 55 and minus 60 are expected tonight. Conditions will improve on Friday. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-06T18:59:03-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-06T04:27:03-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1673768533.2020
Area: Sachs Harbour, Ulukhaktok
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard and dangerous extreme cold developing tonight into Saturday. A low pressure system crossing the northern prairies today will bring a surge of bitterly cold air to Kivalliq tonight as the system moves into Hudson Bay. Northwesterly winds of 50 gusting 70 km/h will develop over the south beginning this evening and expand northeastward into Saturday bringing blowing snow and blizzard conditions to the region. In addition, temperatures by Saturday morning will fall below the -40 degree Celsius mark, producing dangerous extreme cold wind chills in the -60 to -70 range. For the south, winds will gradually ease through the day on Saturday ending the blizzard there. Further north, strong winds and blizzard conditions will continue into Sunday before diminishing. Finally, most sites can expect a second night of extreme cold Saturday night into Sunday before temperatures begin to moderate as well. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-07T01:36:32-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-06T09:37:32-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3010002705.2020
Area: Baker Lake, Arviat, Rankin Region including Whale Cove, Chesterfield Inlet, Naujaat

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions are expected Saturday. Strong to high southerly winds will develop Friday night before turning northwesterly during the day Saturday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wintry weather for this weekend. Total snowfall: between 10 and 20 cm. Locations: northeastern Newfoundland, including Gander and vicinity, Bonavista North and Bay of Exploits, Timespan: Saturday evening until Sunday evening. Remarks: Snow will develop Saturday evening and will persist until Sunday evening. The snowfall rates are expected to remain light to moderate throughout this time. Occasional blowing snow will also develop Saturday night with strengthening northeasterly wind gusts and will ease throughout Sunday as the snow ends and the winds gradually shift to northwesterly and begin to weaken. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-07T00:39:31-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-06T08:40:31-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4153182759.2020
Area: Bay of Exploits, Bonavista North, Gander and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wintry weather for this weekend. Total snowfall: between 15 and 25 cm. Locations: Burin Peninsula, Avalon Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity, Terra Nova and Bonavista Peninsula. Time span: midday Saturday until Sunday evening. Remarks: Snow will develop over the southern Avalon and Burin Peninsulas midday Saturday and spread to the east coast of Newfoundland Saturday evening. The snow will become heavy at times Saturday night with significant snowfall amounts expected. The snowfall rates will ease by Sunday morning and will end from the south to the north throughout the day. There is also the potential for ice pellets or freezing rain over the extreme southeastern Avalon Peninsula Saturday night. Occasional blowing snow will also develop Saturday night with strengthening northeasterly wind gusts and will ease throughout Sunday as the snow ends and the winds gradually shift to northwesterly and begin to weaken. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-07T00:39:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-06T08:40:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2863890320.2020
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, Avalon Peninsula Southeast, St. John's and vicinity, Avalon Peninsula Southwest, Burin Peninsula, Bonavista Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity, Terra Nova

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Further snowfall: 2 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northerly between 60 and 80 km/h. Locations: Rigolet and vicinity and Hopedale and vicinity. Time span: continuing until Friday morning for Hopedale and vicinity, and until this evening elsewhere. Remarks: Snow will taper to flurries tonight. Strong northerly winds will accompany the snow, reducing visibility in blowing snow. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-06T11:53:26-00:00

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Additional snowfall: 10 cm in snow squalls. Maximum wind gusts: 70 km/h. Locations: western Cape Breton. Time span: ending by Friday morning. ### Snow squall warnings are issued when bands of snow form that produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-06T12:24:29-00:00

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts: northeasterly 80 km/h, except 100 along parts of the coast. Locations: Atlantic coast of Nova Scotia. Time span: Beginning after midnight tonight along the South Shore, Saturday morning for Halifax Region, and Saturday afternoon for Eastern Shore. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and reduced visibilities due to blowing snow tonight and Saturday. Total snowfall: 5 cm, possibly reaching 10 cm Maximum wind gusts: 60 to 100 km/h Locations: Atlantic coastal regions of Nova Scotia Time span: tonight and Saturday. Remarks: A low pressure system will intensify near Cape Hatteras today and will track south of Nova Scotia on Saturday. Snow associated with this system is expected reach southwestern Nova Scotia tonight. At this time, the heaviest snow is expected to remain offshore. There is some uncertainty as to how far north the area of snow will spread. A slight deviation in the track of this low will have a significant impact on the snowfall. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-07T00:30:18-00:00
